comments.commentBody: Completely agree Mike, it's more like meat with pasta than pasta with meat sauce!  Found it quite heavy for my own taste, but hubby did enjoy it as is.

Bernie Sanders is exactly where he needs to be on foreign policy. For as long as I can remember, politicians have scared us into submission with constant references to the "dangerous world" that we live in, and from which only they can protect us. For a grotesque example of this kind of fear-mongering, take a look at the GOP debates.
Sanders appears to have no desire, nor any inclination to use fear to manipulate us. He understands that we cannot afford to maintain both an empire (which prioritizes the prerogatives of the military/industrial complex) and a democracy (which is chiefly concerned with promoting the welfare of the citizenry), and like everyone except the military/industrial complex and big media, he chooses the latter.

It was Hillary that voted for and supported GW Bush's trillion dollar escapade into Iraq, while ignorant Bernie stood up against it, despite the clamoring tide of chicken hawks.  You might also consider that the NY Times played no small part in leading the charge to oust Saddam.

Please name one foreign policy achievement on the part of Clinton, from any point in her career.

Her failure as Secretary of State was profound. Losing the Arab Spring, losing Ukraine...I don't see Clinton as strong on foreign policy.
I think Bernie needs to bone up on foreign policy

Martin, you are showing your age. The new generation doesn'the know the Soviet Union and they probably would have embraced Lenin like they embrace Bernie.

It's not complicated. There is no free lunch and people need motivation, unlike plants, in order to be happy. Plants only need soil and water. Bernie thinks people are happy if they have food and shelter and universal healthcare. Unfortunately, the Garden of Eden left the station a long time ago.

My apologies to all who disagree.

I had the same reaction re how much extra time Clinton was allowed to steal.  It's clear that Bernie is a much more civilized gentleman than Hilary is a lady.  She spoke over Bernie repeatedly, and the moderators made no attempt to enforce the time limits.  Bernie needs to figure out a way to get his time without resorting to Clinton's verbal bullying.
I thought Bernie interrupted, or tried to interrupt, more than Hillary. She usually continued to speak over him.

Something that struck me hard was Hillary was given what seemed 3/4's of the air time tonight to go on and on about everything she prepared over the years to say.   She interupted Bernie consistently, didn't ask but went forth to comment on just about everything he said, without the Moderators stepping in.    She was forceful and determined to get in list after list of her accomplishments and deeds....   Very poor Moderation in this sense.   They asked good tough questions, which is great.... but simply gave the platform largely to Hillary.   Yes, Bernie isn't the kind of guy to grab it, or cut her off, and he shouldn't have to.   "Brutally caustic", may have applied to much of Hillary's early statements, but there was also a fair amount of civility shown in this debate, especially by Bernie and by both towards the very end.   Having over 40 years indepth health care experience here in nyc, I feel everything Bernie has said to be based on facts and realities.  We're fortunate in him.

The impressive Mrs. Clinton is nothing if not strong, focused and steadfast---but on what specific policies? What are her real beliefs?
She talks in more generalities and it sounds very good, so she avoids media criticism. Bernie talks in practical specifics, so gets shot down by the main media.

Sanders concrete ideas will indeed work to solve the inequality problem, and that's exactly why the main media shoots him down all the time. It requires challenging our system and the powers that be. They don't want to be seen on that side.

That's why we see little discussion in the Times of his actual ideas and how they would work. He just gets labeled ideological and revolutionary. Both are exaggerations.

One of Hillary's main selling points is being a victim of attacks by the vast right wing conspiracy. Dems sympathize. But what will she actually do?

I've got to remind myself to look up all her accomplishments she claims over 30 years. What actually were they?
Perhaps you should have looked them up before mouthing off  and admitting you know nothing about her.

Proud to be a Democrat. I admire both the candidates, but tonight's debate has sealed my decision to vote for the most accomplished, experienced and tested candidate, Hillary Clinton! She has worn many hats throughout her life and dealt with numerous complex issues and, yes, has made some errors. In comparasion, Bernie Sanders, as good as he is, lacks the variety of experiences and thus has fewer errors to show for it.
Hillary has been hounded from all directions for decades and has remained strong, focused and steadfast! She is a leader! Hillary2016
The overthrow of Gaddafi created one more failed state and haven for ISIS.  So you trust Clinton's "experience"?

As a regular commenter here on the NYT, I am kind of irritated by the invasion of the 1) Republican trolls pretending to be Bernie fans and/or 2) Bernie fans who don’t understand the damage they are doing by perpetuating the lies that the the Republicans have been growing in their Hillary hate chamber for decades and/or 3) women haters.

To all young women Bernie supporters: You have no respect for the history of women’s rights, or you wouldn’t be so quick to talk trash about a woman running for president. Like Bernie all you want, but stop trying to destroy the woman in the race.

Bill & Hillary Clinton have worked hard for decades on behalf of the America people, but Sanders has emerged as the more presidential candidate. It is unfortunate someone of the caliber of Hillary Clinton is the establishment’s standard bearer at the very moment the establishment is recognizing how thin the ice is beneath so much special interest money. Hillary should not take this repudiation so personally. Rather than digging in her heels to defend the errant paths taken in recent decades, she should embrace the challenge and opportunity Sanders is leading to return the Democratic Party to the American people..

I completely agree. After the debate, I put up a short post on FB expressing how refreshing it was - again - to see two candidates thoughtfully and civil express their positions. Tons agreed. Then, this morning, I opened the NYT to find this article and wondered if I'd missed something.
What's happened to this paper?

Well, she did dismantle him. She rightly accused him of smear tactics. Then he made an "awwww" sound, and he proceeded to repeat the smear without specifically answering her challenge to him. You should pay attention, maybe re-watch the debate yourself, or read the transcript. Bernie is only offering up angel food cake for everyone sometimes with vague ideas about action. He has embarked on a destructive ego trip, and will take you down with him.

I think I must have been watching a different debate from the one written about here by Martin and Healy. The "bitterness and rancor" angle is highly overblown. Long before candidates entered the second half of the debate, the tone became almost too civil on both sides. I think they both realized they were being set up for a semantic food fight. And thanks to the subsequent relative dearth of "gotchas" by the moderators, I was able to learn a lot more about their positions. They actually spoke in complete, uninterrupted paragraphs. What a refreshing change from the boilerplate soundbites we've come to expect from the GOP's fascist clowns.

If you happened to miss the debate and were relying solely upon this article for a recap, you were sadly misled. Clinton did not launch a harshest of all harsh attacks on Sanders. If anything, she disingenuously overreacted to his correct observation that Wall Street has an outsize influence on politicians and his call to do away with the legalized bribery of Citizens United.

Yet the opening paragraph of this piece would have you believe that Clinton destroyed Sanders in one fell swoop. Huh?

This is the Times doing what it does best: diminishing/attacking Bernie Sanders through the same insinuation and innuendo that Clinton ascribed to her opponent. It's a terminal case of journalistic OCD, and apparently highly resistant to the usual therapy of fairness and accuracy.

For a clear picture, simply watch the debate or read the transcript.

Barack Obama gets a good deal of praise because he actually opposed the Iraq invasion from the beginning.  But Clinton has learned from the past few years, and only the Republicans haven't.  We live in a world vastly different from the one we lived in twenty or so years ago, in some ways better and in some ways worse.  We have to be ready to deal with the world we live in today, and also the one we will live in tomorrow.  Of course it helps to remember the past and how many people voted for the Tonkin Gulf resolution or to impeach President (Andrew) Johnson.  We can avoid making yesterday's mistakes tomorrow.

What has Clinton learned more recently. She keeps talking about rubbing shoulders with Kissinger, Bush, and whoever might give her status by association. Since she now is glued to Obama, quite the opposite when she criticized him in 2008, using some of the same lightweight comments she now does against Sanders, what influence did she have on the current problems/policies in Iraq, Iran, and the other Mideast countries. After all, she keeps talking about how much experience she has. Did she influence any of Obama's current policies as Secretary of State. She keeps saying she had influence when Obama gave the orders against Bin Laden. There is an iconic photo where she is in the same room. By the looks of her expression she appeared to not be confident about going after Bin Laden. Are there transcripts of what role she played in that decision. Otherwise, being near or at the decision-making point doesn't necessarily mean you made the decisions. If she were to win the primary, she is going to have to own up to wrapping herself around Obama in the general election. It will be hard to pivot and disclaim all being said now about how in agreement she now appears to be with Obama, both on domestic issues/policies/programs and on foreign issues/policies/program.

If War Criminal Henry Kissinger, who has been reportedly fearful of travelling abroad so as not to be arrested and indicted by the World Court in The Hague, approves of Hillary, that scares the daylights out of me.

Hillary Clinton in tonight's debate continues to not be consistent in what she says. She has a problem of dropping names of people from the past, like Henry Kissinger, who she said praised her. She states how she wants to continue what Obama has done, most likely to win minority voters. Yet on foreign policy she fails to be accountable to the current state of chaos in the region. She voted for the Iraq invasion and was Secretary of State for four years. Incoherent to say how her years as Secretary of State did not contribute to the current chaos in the region. She'll take credit from anyone but not assume accountability. Someone that only takes credit but is not accountable will be like having George W. Bush again; she also has praised George W. Bush. She clearly is the establishment candidate. In previous town hall she disrespected the youth asking questions about being dishonest. She seems to think by having been through the wringer that she will enjoy that same type of battle; instead of bringing opposing sides together. She appears to speak a language of the past and sounds not current, both in her proposed plans and in the way she speaks. Hard to see how she would energize the base, youth, and minorities. She should have said Sanders was electable in a general election. And should release the transcripts of her paid for speeches. She seems to whine at the slightest comment. Sanders could have truly lobbed major attacks but shows more class.

Much as I like Barack Obama, he was unable to deliver any change to how wealth is distributed in the U.S. His slogans for change, were largely just that.
And the reason is, President Obama entered the Presidency powerless and has remained powerless for seven years.
Bernie will experience the exact same phenomena, he will enter the White House powerless, and will continue to be powerless for the length of his tenure as President.
Hillary on the other hand, and despite her vilification by extreme Republicans, actually already wields enormous clout, and will be able to accomplish some real reform, make reasonable nominations, and generally push forward a moderate, but progressive agenda.
That is something that Bernie, I believe, will not be able to do.

In fairness, that came later because Bernie does everything he can to avoid making it personal. She came loaded for bear, trying to make a mountain out of a molehill, and playing the victim. It is disengenuious and cynical. She started off as if she thought she was in the GOP debate. Bernie sidesteps opportunities to attack her because he thinks those attacks are a distraction and a disservice to voters. He sticks to the issues. He leads from a moral center. He is a man of honor.
Did the Times watch the same debate I did? Rather than witnessing a series of brutal, caustic attacks, I saw and heard two candidates exchanging views in an extraordinarily civil manner.

Excellent debate as the focus was clearly on the issues both big and small.  Both candidates seem equally electable in my opinion.  What may have impressed me the most was each candidate debated with dignity as well as showing respect for their peer.  They are both class acts.

And for what reason would the former Wall Street financiers leave that to run a B&B in Vermont? Could it be that the were sick of the corrupt financial system which Sanders assails and sought a life with greater personal integrity? My bet is that Sanders resonates most with those voters.
Hilary is, like Trump, a verbal bully.

I did not think Sanders was honorable and plain-spoken. He eluded many questions and then he claimed Obama was progressive and Hillary was not. The both accepted money from Wall Street. Sanders was doing lots of double speak there. If you are not touched by Bernie mania, you can see all the calculations and pandering that goes on when Bernie talks. He does promise the moon to get votes and it is a moon he know he can't deliver. Bernie has only been a career politician most of his life, finally winning an election when he was about 40. He is just spinning and manipulating the voters. He wasn't even a Democrat for most of his life. He's claiming to be a Democrat now that he wants to win the nomination. He is not an honorable man.
Hardly.  She is strong and not in any way shape or form at all like Trump.

This debate was a clear victory for Mr. Sanders. He is honorable, plain-spoken, focused and in the eyes of many, ever more credible as the nominee. I am proud to be a Sanders supporter tonight. Onwards!

I remember the first Jewish wedding I ever attended, some 50+ years ago, and being mystified by the thing with the chairs. Many years and many weddings later, I still am. I wonder if there are any stats on how many people have been injured by this tradition and wound up honeymooning in the emergency room.

Good idea re the bird. I loved the clip.
PS:  At least one of those weddings was at the Mt. NEBO(h) Temple.

and Elke
No way to SKIRT the issue-- I needed a vigorous Google workout for the long and short names. But A MODEST PROPOSAL was in my wheelhouse; it is a most macabre satire.
Seeing HORA just above GRAND STAND SEATS reminds me that at Jewish weddings bride and groom are LIFTED up on chairs while guests dance the HORA. One hand of bride hanging on to chair and dressSKIRT for dear life, the other hand connected to groom via flimsy handkerchief.
Noticed presence of GAGA, LOON, ADDLEd , (T)NUT - all synonyms for crazy ?
Deb- wonderful video of the puzzle solving bird. I guess when birds became flightless (like emus), their brains took a REST or LEAKed out. Could that bird be hired for weekend blog monitoring duty?? Pay could be all the OHS it can eat. Just a PROPOSAL...
Harder than usual for me. Fair, but WHAT MORE CAN I SAY ? Liked it nevertheless.
9:10 pm PST

She's part of the solution too.  The problem will be much, much worse if the Democrats lose.  And she's much more likely to win.  Still, if he gets the nomination, I'll probably revise my views, since if he get it, I'll have to concede that he's pretty good at campaigning too.

@Andylit

Did you mean to include among your "underachievers" our socialized police, fire, and EMT departments? Our public hospitals, libraries, and schools? Heck, if you want to be honest about it, even some private sectarian schools, if they're collectively owned and operated by a religious congregation, might be considered to be "socialist" insofar as the books, desks, and physical plant, i.e., capital, are owned and controlled by the governing body and its members… and not one individual.

But while we're discussing: Some private charter schools -- nowhere near our 'socialistic' public school model -- have been doing more than their fair share of distributing "mediocrity."

Very clever way to encourage people like me who would probably go with Hillary to jump to Bernie instead, just out of pique with comments like this -- pushing Bernie being of course the Republican preference.  Well done.

Hillary represents the establishment that got us to where we are today. It wasn't college students who created the hell on earth in the Middle East. Nor did they cause a global financial catastrophe in 2008. Restarting the Cold War and always trying to pick a fight with China aren't their ideas either. And what could be more establishment than the certainty that the Republican presidential candidate will be a climate change denier.

Bernie Sanders is doesn't want to do anything crazy, that's been the establishment's role for decades. Personally I'd rather have free higher education than modernization of the nuclear arsenal.
As James demonstrates in his comment, some Bernie supporters just can't acknowledge Hillary's grit and valuable experience. It's hard to take them seriously.

New York Times have already sided with the establishment candidate even though they know better.

Now they are trying to justify their choice by labeling (mislabeling) Bernie supporters as gullible idealistic youth.

I am a Bernie supporter abut I am not that young. The establishment spin masters criticize Bernie's plans as farfetched/pie in the sky etc.

In the Federal Budget there is more than enough money to do what Bernie is advocating, a re apportionment of priorities is necessary to balance our budget. Maybe some Senators/Congressmen would have to forego 'bridge to nowhere' etc.

Free college education is something that was given right here in the most populous State of the Union California not too long ago.

Re single payer healthcare delivery system, it is being practiced in many OECD countries and with good results at much lower cost.

One thing for sure, our youth is much more educated at this age with smart phones and VR platforms than we were at their age. Please my cohorts give them credit for their easy access to facts and quick decision making prowess.

With all due respect sir, there is no need to try scaring people into voting for Clinton over future terrorist threats. That is exactly what Republicans do, in particular what Bush and Cheney did to win back the White House in 2004. Both the Republicans and Hillary Clinton, with her 3am phone call ad, tried this tactic to derail President Obama, and obviously there have been no attacks launched at the USA on his watch.
No, this is not the 1930's and Sanders is not FDR. This is 2016 when income inequality, perhaps the defining issue of our time, is worse than it was in the roaring 20's. I don't believe Secretary Clinton, with her deep connections to Wall Street, has the right stuff to take on these huge injustices. Bernie Sanders is that person.

Don't believe that's the case. In my situation I want to work and become an engineer but schooling fund and the projects available for me are limited. Bernie is the only candidate I hear with a plan to rebuild our infrastructure , repair campaign financing , and get millennials educated/working without crashing the economy with the coming student loan bubble.
@Hank, do people believe these national polls taken a year before most candidates have been introduced to the country in any serious way?  Why bother -- we do not have national elections anyway.

How I love these comments!
Young and old, we're seeing and feeling the same thing.
My wife and I (73 and 77) are with you, with Bernie.
